div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.

div.head: Important Announcement.
div.p: Steam Ploughing, Cultivating, Levelling and Grading.

Messrs. J. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principals, will be in Egypt for the month of March 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them our team plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will also show them our new Patient Gasobeah, or levelling scoop, at work, which is the most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yet been put upon the market.
Landed Proprietors, Agriculturists, and Contractors, are requested to communicate with Mr. McLAREN at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo, after March 1st, 1906.

SATURDAY, MARCH 24, 1906.

div.head: EUROPE'S FUTURE: RETRENCHMENT OR REVOLUTION.
div.p: With the exception of Russia. Lord Avebury in th. "Nineteenth Century '' says, the greatStates of Europe cannot produce the food required by their people, even at the present rate of living. They all import food and export manufactures. Take away the market for their manufactures and they will be unable to buy the food they require. Until recently, however, they have had no effective competition. The United States were, till within the last few years, mainly an agricultural commodity. Even now they require most of their manufactures for home use. Gradually, however, the surplus is increasing and the competition becoming more severe, Our great Colonies, moreover, wisely or unwisely

- unwisely as I think-are all endeavouring to check the development of their great tracts of virgin soil, and to foster the town at the expense of the country. Take Canada, for instance, and look at the effect of Canadian duties on Canada herself. The winters -are very cold, and she compels her people to pay 10, 15, or even 20 per cent. more than they need for warm clothing. She needs railways to develop her magnificent agricultural districts in the West, and she artificially enhances the prices of rails. When I think over these things I sometimes doubt whether men have reason after all! But the military and naval expenditure of the Colonies is trifling. They decline to bear any fair proportion of our expenses on the Army and Navy, and are technically within their right in doing so. We cannot, if we would, compel them, and would not if we could. If they contribute it must be done voluntarily. Only they must remember that there are at present no Imperial forces. The Army and Navy are entirely supported by, and belong to, the British Isles. If a colony gets into trouble with any first-class Power, any assistance we might give would be an act of grace ; they cannot claim it as a right. The military and naval expenditure of the United States and of our Colonies is then very small compared with ours and that of other European States. Competition with America and our Colonies is therefore becoming more and more difficult. Manufactures will, cateris paribus, gradually be transferred to the countries which are most lightly taxed. This will more and more aggravate the evil, so that unless we turn over a new leaf the prospects of Europe are very grave. In fact, as long as these armaments are maintained we are sitting on a volcano. The enormous and wasteful expenditure of Europe means lower with higher prices of the necessaries of life, and harder work. It makes life a heavier, and for millions an almost intolerable, burden. ... Bayonets are good as weapons, but not to sit on... Unless something is done the condition of the poor in Europe will grow worse and worse. It is no use shutting our eyes. Revolution may not come soon, not probably in our time, but come it will, and as sure as fate there will be an explosion such as the world has never seen. If the monarchs of Europe are to retain their thrones, and if we are to maintain peace, European statesmen must devise some means of fostering better feelings, and diminishing the burdens which now press so heavily on the springs of industry and aggravate so terribly the unavoidable troubles of life. Is this hopeless? … Is it altogether utopian to suggest that come representatives of the navies of England, France, Germany, and Russia might meet and agree on a common basis, not, of course, as binding on, but as a suggestion to their respective Governments? .... I have argued the question mainly on material and economical grounds. But, after all, we ought not to forget that we are a Christian people. The present state of Borope is discreditable to us not only as men of common sense, but as being altogether inconsistent with any form of religious convictions ? … "

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Regulations as against plague are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Jamnagar.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to March 22 amounted to 253 355 tons, as compared with 141,378 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: Sailors' Home Harbour Mission,
div.p: Mr. Jos. E. Datton will exhibit his large and beautiful model of the Tabernacle of Israel on Sunday next. The explanation will be given at 7.30 p. m. All are invited.

div.head: Thirty "Hashasheen" Arrested.
div.p: A hashish café at Bab El Louk, Cairo, was raided on Wednesday evening. It was crowded with a large number of hashasheen when the police appeared. A quantity of hashish was confiscated and 30 of its devotees were taken to the nearest caracol.

div.head: Tramway Accident.
div.p: This morning, at about 8 45 o'clock, the train coming from the Palace station to Alexandria knocked down a young Greek servant girl in the employment of Mr. Athanasias Sanicos. The girl escaped by a miracle with only some slight contusions.

div.head: Boulac Reformatory.
div.p: The construction of the new reformatory at Boulac-Dacroar is proceeding rapidly. The coat of the building is estimated at LE. 100,000. It will be thirteen feddans in extent and will he divided into two parts, for the two sexes. There will be a mosque and workshops attached.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: Last night, the Coast Guards received information that there was contraband on board a steamer in Alexandria harbour named the Byzantion. The vessel was watched, and two sacks, containing 110 kilos of hashish, which were thrown overboard, were seized. Two well-known smugglers, who were on board and threw the sacks into the water were also apprehended.

div.head: Alexandria Tramway Co.
div.p: Some local newspapers have announced that the Board of Directors of the Alexandria Tramway Company will shortly inangarate a motor-bus service in the main streets where there are no tram lines. But we are informed that no definite decision has as yet been arrived at on this subject ; it is at present merely a project and nothing more. The scheme is of course quite distinct from the new motor-bus company, which is to be formed soon in Alexandria.

div.head: Alexandria Employes.
div.p: The fourth annual general meeting of the lnternational Society of Alexandria Employés was held last night in the hall of the Conservatoire of Music. The chairman, Mr. George Rublié, opened the meeting, which was very largely attended. He gave an account of the satisfactory progress and the sound financial condition of the institution which now counts about four hundred members. The election of the new committee of twenty members then took place. The following were elected :- J. Dendrinos, A. Meravelli, J. Mignot, B. Paris, G. Rablie, Santarelli, Sarkis, J. Boulos, Stamatopoulo, A Uliot, Taraggi, Belleli, L. d'Amico, A. Levy, Salama, Oragio Giorgi, Vaotlsier, Sabella, Agiman, Stienberg, Mlinarich. Messre. Brunone, Mandini, and Ranguis were appointed auditors. At a forthcoming meeting there will be an election of the new chairman and other officers.

div.head: Spend your Holidays at Mena.
div.p: The management of Mena Honge Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [Advt.]

div.head:
THE ROYAL GOVERNOR
DATE OF PRINCE'S ARRIVAL.
div.p: STATE BANQUET AT ABDEEN PALACE.

The Prince and Princess of Wales, who are expected in Cairo on Thursday next from Suez, where they arrive on Wednesday, will be entertained at a State banquet at Abdeen Palace by H. H. the Khedive on the following Saturday.
The Prince and Princess will be met on arrival at Suez by Col. Watson, A. D. C., representing the Khedive, and Mr. M. de C. Findlay representing Lord Cromer.

Their Royal Highnesses will be the guests of Lord and Lady Cromer on the 4th April, and after dinner & reception will be held at the British Agency, for which a large number of invitations will be issued.
We understand that before leaving Cairo T. R. H. will honour the American Diplomatic Agency by their presence at a garden party.

div.head: MANSOURAH'S PROGRESS.
div.p: Mansourah is the most advanced of the provincial centre of population in the Delta, and all who are interested in the progress of Egypt will read the report of the working of the Municipal Commission of that town from 1899 to the end of 1905. The Mixed Municipal Commission of Mansourah was founded by a Khedivial decree in June, 1881, but the institution did not have any practical existence until the end of 1898, owing to the difficulty of persuading the various elements of the population to pay a municipal tax without which a Municipal Commission could not exist. But in 1903 the discontent with the institution showed itself by many of the inhabitants of the town officially notifying, "par acte d'huissier," the chairman of the Commission that they would no longer agree to pay the tax.

Mustapha Pacha Maher, the Moudir of Dakaklieh, Chairman of the Commission, however, succeeded in persuading them to renew their engagement as to the municipal tax for a third triennial period, from 1905 to 1907, and he gave them an undertaking to publish a conscientious account of the actual situation of the Municipality. This publication has just been issued and it is a very useful document for all those (we do not believe they are many) who take an interest in the development of municipal institutions in Egypt. The subjects treated of are naturally excessively local and of no interest to anyone outside the town. But they show that Mansourah is steadily progressing and that the persons responsible for the control of the Municipal Commission have some ideas of civic duty.

We congratulate Mustapha Pacha Maher on his labours, for the report he has drawn up should convince the people of Mansourah that they get a good deal of value for a very light burthen of taxation, and that the Egyptian Government is doing its best to help them in advancing the well-being of one of the most pleasant provincial towns in Egypt.

div.head:
THE MINET-EL-BASSAL FIRE.
AN AMERICAN'S INTERESTING QUERIES.
div.p: The adjustment committee have finished the settlement of all the claims arising out of the recent great cotton fire at Minet-el-Bassal. It is very satisfactory to find how speedily the enormous amount of work, which has had to pass through the committee's hands, has been transacted.

Within less than two months of the configuration the parties interested, namely, two of the most important cotton-exporting firms in Egypt, have received the total amount claimed by them. Such expedition is unknown in similar cases in Europe. Here it is due to the liberal and easy terms of the agents of the insurance companies, who have done all they can to satisfy claimants as they are in this case well aware of the bona fides of all the firms concerned.

We know perfectly well that the work of salvage has been a record, for over 1,930 bale steam pressed, were put on sale out of the whole lot of 1,280 pressed bales damaged, producing, with a few insignificant items added, over L.E. 35,000. This is in a great measure due to the celerity of the adjustment committee and also to the great judgment exercised by Mr. Frank Haselden, whose competence and resources for dealing with such crises are unparalleled in Egypt.
A New York correspondent has prt to the "Manchester Guardian" certain questions with reference to the above fire, which the journal confesses its inability to answer. The letter is as follows :-

"Referring to the recent cotton fire at the Choremi Press in Alexandria, Egypt, kindly let me know in what condition the bulk of the bales were after the fire. I mean as compared to bales which were not so heavily compressed. What density did these bales have? Also what pressure was used (per square inch) in compressing them? Was the fire due to spontaneous combustion of the cotton? What is the greatest density obtained either by steam or hydraulic compressing? What is the limit of pressure which can be used in compressing a cotton bale? These are interesting questions, and it is possible that some of our readers can throw light on them.

div.head:
THE COTTON WORM.
AN INTERESTING REPORT.
LARGE GATHERING AT KHEDIVIAL.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria was thronged with a large and fashionable crowd, representative of all sections of Alexandria Society, on the occasion of the farewell. "At Home" given by H. B. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, who took this opportunity of saying goodbye to the many friends he has made at Alexandria during his tenure of office. The great ball-room of the hotel presented a most brilliant appearance from 5 to 7 o'clock, and the reception was in every respect a very delightful function.

Among those present were the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps at Alexandria, the Admirals and officers of the American and Austro-Hungarian Squadrons now in harbour, Chitty Bay, Director-General of the Customs Administration, Dr. Schiess Pacha, Vice-President of the Alexandria Municipality, Rear-Admiral Sir Massia and Lady Blomfield, Colonel Bird and the officers of the R. Dublin Fusiliers, the Commandant of the Alexandria City Police and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Mansour Bey Youssef, Riaz Bey, Ayoub Bey, &o.
The Alexandria Municipality will give a banquet on Tuesday next in honour of the Governor of Alexandria.
The members of the Mohamed Aly Club will entertain his Excellency to a banquet on Wednesday, and the Consular Corps will give a banquet to him on Thursday.

div.head: FAYOUM FOSSIL ANIMALS.
div.p: Dr. Andrews has arrived in Egypt from the British Museum Natural History Department to make further collections of the fossil animals in the Lybian hills along the Fayoum. Especial endeavours will be made to obtain additional specimens of the Arsinoitheriom, and of the earlier varieties of the elephant and reptilian species. A portion of the result will be reserved for the Cairo Natural History Museum.

div.head: AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC AGENCY.
div.p: The American Diplomatic Agency in Egypt has lost one of its most popular members by the departure of the Hon. Fred. Morgan, who has resigned the post of Vice-Consul-General which he has held for over three years, and left on Wednesday for Marseilles. A large gathering of friends was present at the railway station to wish him good-bye. Mr. Morgan will in all probability resign the diplomatic service altogether. His handsome residence and grounds at Kasr-el Doubara were lately sold to the Princess, former wife of H.H. Prince Abmed Fouad Pachs. The mansion is at present occupied by the American Agency, but as the lease of the house, when sold in November was for one year, the offices of the Agency and Consulate will have to be removed elsewhere at that date.
Mr. Grew, the Deputy Consul-General, who has been appointed to the Embassy at Mexico, will leave Cairo as soon as his successor is named.

div.head: AMERICAN SQUADRON.
div.p: As already briefly announced, H. H. the Khedive will entertain Rear-Admiral Sigabee and his flag lieutenant, together with 18 other senior officers of the squadron at an official dinner at Abdeen Palace this evening, There will also be present the Hon. L. M. Iddings, Diplomatic Agent of America, and Mrs. Iddings, Mr. G. C. Grew, Deputy Consul-General, and Mrs. Grew, Mr. and Mr. Leigh Hunt, Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Ewing, Judge and Mrs. Tuck, and Mr. and Mrs. Bacon, besides the members of the Khedive's Civil and Military Household.

A delightful "At Home" was given onboard the flagship Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The guests included Mr., Mrs. and Miss Hewat, Mr. and Mrs. Borchgrevink, Judge and Miss Batobeller, Judge and Mrs. Vapai Horn, Col., Mrs. and Miss Bird, Capt., Mrs. and Miss Crawley, Mr, Mrs. and Miss Peel, etc.
After the "At Home," a large number of the officers from the ships attended the reception given by H.E. the Governor.

Judge and Miss Batcheller gave a dinner yesterday evening at Ramleh to Admiral Sigsbee and a number of the officers. This afternoon Mr. and Mrs. Hewat are giving a dancing reception in honour of the naval officers.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT.
div.p: The renewal of the commercial convention between Egypt and Greece has been decided upon. No alteration is to be made up the position of Greek tobacco, nor in the Capitulations. The Greek Government will be allowed until the 15th June for the ratification of the convention by the Athenian Chamber of Deputies. The convention will continue for eight years.

div.head: THE MAHMAL.
div.p: A telegram from Tor states that the Khedivial steamer Rahmarieh arrived from Yamen on Thursday with the Sacred Carpet and suite, composed of 577 persons. The ship doctor declared one ordinary case of sickness but no death.
The S.S. Merirut arrived at Tor from Yamen to on Thursday with 818 pilgrims.

div.head:
CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
div.p: LA FAILLITE DES SUCRERIES

The Ministry of the lnterior has issued a full and interesting report on the cotton worm in 1905. The experience of last year taught cultivators and officials much that they did not know before, and the cotton worm, which had hitherto done such a vast amount of injury, last year did absolutely none.

If the Government had not taken up the matter of the worm, the result would have been disastrous for the crop. All the lessons learned are to be applied this year, and until such time as every cultivator can be relied upon to look after his own crops.
Many of the modifications indicated as desirable will be adopted, and it is to be hoped the sympathy and the support of the population can be relied upon.

Improved seed and artificial mandres will continue to be supplied by the Khedivial Agricultural Society, and the executive may be relied upon to renew its exertions ; but the mystery of the boil-worm must be solved, and an effort must be made to see whether it will not be possible to evolve some means of dealing more scientifically with the water which the Irrigation Department can supply Scepticism, apathy and inertia on the part of the smaller cultivators were the chief difficulties with which the authorities had to contend. The moudirieh and markaz officials at once grasped the importance of their task, and responded to the call, but some of the omdehs and sheikhs could not be induced to take it seriously until a certain number of punishments had been inflicted and the smaller fellaheen only began to believe when they saw that their cotton from which they had collected so many millions of eggs was now healthy and strong, whereas last year in many cases nothing but the wood was left. "These English learned about the worm from books," said a fellah in Mazala, and another in Faraqur told an inspector that he would have done all this long ago if he had known that the worms came from eggs and could be destroyed.

The fellah is quite unable to work out his own salvation, but when once he has been forcibly convinced that his interest lies in certain direction his opposition gradually ceases. For years he has seen Europeans and wealthier proprietors clean their land with certain measure of success, but it required, Decree and a very vigorous application, of make him do anything himself be blamed. He abstained

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: According to the native Press, the Khedivah-Mother intends making a pilgrimage to Mecca this year. Her Highness will be accompanied by a numerous suite.
Lady Cromer's brother, the Marquis of Bath, has been appointed chairman of the Wilts County Council, in succession to Lord Fitzmaurice.
M. Skouzos, the Hellenic Minister for Foreign Affairs, gave a banquet at Athens last week in honour of the Hellenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Egypt.

Rear-Admiral von Jedina, of the Austro-Hungarian Squadron, accompanied by his two daughters, has gone to Cairo for a few days' stay. He will return to Alexandria on Friday next and has reserved apartments at the Carlton Hotel until the sailing of the squadron.

The Khedive has conferred the rank of Mirmiran on Commendatore Luzzatto, the general manager of the Bank of Egypt. This mark of his Highness favour will be much appreciated by Alexandrians, who greatly respect the character of their distinguished fellow townsman. We congratulate the new Pacha.

Lieut. Colonel Count Gleichen, C. V. O., D S. O., late Grenadier Guards, has taken up his duties as Military Attaché at Washington. The appointment, an American paper says, "has given satisfaction, because Count Gleichen's reputation as a student of armies stands high, and it is known that he will carry out his duties with a fall appreciation of the social as well as the professional claims made upon him."

Among the passengers who left Alexandria yesterday afternoon by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal were Mr. and Mrs. Heaton Armstrong, General de Larnac, Viscount Lavarus, Mrs. and Miss Crawley, the Rev. Mr. Whitehead, Mrs. Gounard, and Mr. and Mrs. Straker-Wilson.

div.head:
GERMANY AND RUSSIA.
COUNT LAMSDORFF'S TELEGRAM.

div.p: The Press is angry at Count Lamsdorff's telegram to Algeciras and accuses Russia of duplicity and ingratitude.
(Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN STRIKES.
RENEWAL EXPECTED IN APRIL.

div.p: The Russian Government is feverishly preparing for the expected renewal of strikes in April : armoured trains are ready along all the railways : Signor Marooni is supervising a plan for installing wireless telegraphy throughout the Empire.
The governors and prefects have received orders to arrest and punish pupils who absent themselves from schools in sympathy with Lieutenant Schmidt.
(Reuter)

div.head:
BIG LABOURITE BILL.
GREAT NATIONALISATION SCHEME.

div.p: The draft of a Labourite Bill for the nationalisation of mines, canals, railways, and tramways has been published. (Reuter)

The terms with reference to the Transvaal Committee urge special consideration as to the desirability of substituting manhood suffrage for £10 franchise provided in Mr. Lyttelton's constitution, and to rearrange the constituencies according to local circumstances. The labour question is not mentioned. (Reuter)
A large number of Parliamentarians have given a banquet to M. Combes and presented him with a commemorative gold medal for the services rendered to the democracy. (Havas)
The rumour which has been current abroad that the Emperor is ill, is entirely unfounded.
(Havas)

div.head: RAS MAKONNEN DEAD.
div.p: ADDIS ABEBA, March 23.
Ras Makonnen is dead. (Reuter)

The death of Ras Makonnen is an important matter for Abyssinia as he was always held to be the probable successor of Menelik as Emperor of Abyssinia, for Menelik has no children. Res Makonnen, it will be remembered, was designated by the Emperor as his representative at King Edward's coronation, and Earopeans who have visited Abyssinia have almost invariably carried away the impression that, notwithstanding the absence of any formal indication of his wishes, Menelik was anxious to prepare the way for Ras Makonnen's succession to the Abyssinian Throne in the event of his own decease. Ras Makonnen was distinguished from the general bulk of the high officials who constitute the ruling class in Abyssinia. Mr. Angostas B. Wylde described him as "by far the cleverest and most enlightened man that the country possesses," and other Earopeans who have been brought into personal or official relations with him hwe formed a similarly high estimate of his character and talents. His exact age does not appear to be known, or at any rate to have been recorded, but he was probably a little over forty years.

In character, no less than in attainments. Ras Mekonnen stood somewhat apart both from the general body of his countrymen and from other members of the ruling class. The Abyssinian soldier is by nature a roystering, swaggering fellow, and since the defeat of the Italians Europeans travelling in the country have not infrequently had to complain of the conduct of the undisciplined bands of soldiery whom they encountered. Ras Makonnen was brave and a tried soldier, as be proved on many expeditions against rebellious chiefs and in the Italian campaign, but there was nothing of the swaggerer in his composition, Physically he was not a strong man, and in a country where religion is little more than a name he had the reputation of being some bing of a religions enthusiast. M. Hugues le Roux, one of the most recent European visitors to Abyssinia, gives a vivid little pen picture of the man: "Il est difficile de se figurer un visage plus charmant. Devant ce profil si fio,ces grands yeux presque trop expressifs et eu l'extase religieuse apparaît comme volonté, remplaçant l'ironie sémite, on songe aux petits christs byzantine, tout en expression, tout en âme, cachant dans les plis d'un étroit manteau on corps asce ique." Another French traveller, M. Charles Michel, who visited Abyssinia as second in command of the Bonchamps Mission, which was intended to join hands from the Abyssinian side with the Marchand Expedition at Fashoda, has also placed on his impressions of Ras Makonnen, He described him as a grand sei neur of the olden time, "très froid, très réflé-hi, et très digne," who impressed himself on the French traveller as being "quelqu'un." Further acquaintance only served to strengthen the original impression, and M. Micbel states as a remarkable and, indeed, in Abyssinia an astonishing fact that not only was Ras Makonnen full of dignity but that he was a man of irreproachable life.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
M. LE BARGY'S COMPANY.
div.p: M. Le Bargy and his colleagues are here at last and have so far given two performances Le Marquis de Priola and Le Demi Monde What a change from the usual "show" at the theatre! Real acting, and real plays, instead of the sham boredom with so few relieving touches, endured (if not even admired!) by the unchanging audience of the Khedivial Opera House. For all that, the audience was much the same as usual : there were the familiar faces, and the familiar cough, rustle, and whispered mistranslation from French into Arabic of this or that phrase. It is indeed difficult to follow and listen to plays under such circumstances ; and that is my chief excuse for giving no more than a general impression of both the plays so far presented. M. Le Bargy and Mlle. Baréty are certainly the two stars, and so far each has had one great part, he as le Marquis de Priola, and she as Mme d'Ange. He is infinitely and delightfully varied, dignified, fiery-"fougueux" is the real word, - "subtle and persuasive" ; in fact the real "homme d'esprit." Somehow, though, there were moments in the Marquis de Priola where he seemed to force the note, to be too ardent and emphatic ; but the rapid delicacy of his "courtship" scenes, with their subdued fire, were a delight. That play is what most worthy people would call "very French," but for all its cynicism, it has something most natural throughout, and typical.

The other play, Le Demi Monde, is older, and more psychological possibly, longer, and except for most of the last three acts, not so interesting. But those acts : the end of the 3rd, the 4th, and the beginning of the finale, these are great, and Mlle. Baréty gave a great interpretation. Every glance, intonation, gesture, was reality, painful and absorbing. I was able to follow that part, as the audience were really held by it, and, relatively speaking, one could bear all that was said on the stage.

We have Le Duel to-night, one of M. le Bargy's great parts. The whole programme indeed is good. The rest of the caste seemed to me to be quite adequate, not exactly wonderful but well able to appear with credit in the company of the two stars: and that says much. Mlle. Bernou was perhaps the best. M. Dauvillier was good as de Nanjac, very good now and again. It will be easier to criticise after a few more performances, and when we have seen the various "sides" of all these performers : certainly M. Le Bargy and Mlle. Baréty are in themselves a whole world of different phases of humanity : it is an education to see such acting.

div.head: CONSTIPATION
div.p: To ensure a natural movement of the bowels, it is most important to take plenty of exercise every day. Many men and women don't do this, and they become more or less costive, sometimes going two or three days without a passage from the bowels. This is a very serious thing, not only because constipation makes our food and blood impure, but because the prolonged presence of waste matter in the bowels strains the muscular walls,eventually paralysing them, so that instruments have to be used to remove the impurities.

Those who cannot get enough exercise, or whose work is sedentary, should use Doan's Dinner Pills, which are made from pure roots and herbs that act on the bowels, invigorating the muscular walls, and toning up the nerves, liver, stomach, and whole digestive organism. p.hi: BY JOHN WARD, F.S.A. Assisted by Sir REGINALD WINGATE and his Officers, Sir WILLIAM CARSTIN, Lt-Cols COUNT

div.p: Dedicated by request to
LORD KITCHENER OF KHARTOUM.
Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward, -Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little buast to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the 'Peace and Progress' is, in fact, a sequel to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.'
With kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely,
RUDOLF V. SLATIN.

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES.
div.p: About forty representatives of British sport have now signified their intention to compete for the laurels of the great Olympia meeting to be held at Athens from April 22 to May 2 and to be crowned, if victorious, by the King of the Hellenes, after the fashion of the ancient festival, which is to be reproduced so far as is possible in the revival.

The British committee brought their labours to an end last week and considering the difficulties which they have had to overcome they are to be complimented on the exceptionally good contingent they have got together. If it is not so representative nor so strong as it might have been it is not the fault of the committee, but of circumstance, which they could not control. There are athletes who are not included whom one would have liked to see upholding the British colours on the famous field. But Greece is a long way, and several leading amateurs could not give up the necessary time. It is unfortunate, also, that the United Kingdom will have no representative in a number of the competitions. including booting, wrestling, lawn tennis, football, and the tug-of war. The United States is more largely represented-sixty three competitors go forward. But the Uniteł States Government gave a grant of £4,000 and officially encouraged the movement in other ways, whereas the British Government has done nothing.

Britain, however has no reason to complain of the men who will represent her in the events which are to be contested. The list, which is complete except that the competitors in the swimming, cycling, and gymnastic sections, although damsd, have not been definitely selected (Mr. John Matthews and Mr. A. Ruskin are certain starters in the bicycle races), is as follows :-
Mr. S. S. Abrahams.--100 and 400 metres. Long jump.
Mr. W. D. Anderson.-400, 800, and 1500 metres.
Mr. S. Carnelly.-5 mile, Marathon race.
Mr. A. R. Churchill.-1500 metres. 5 mile.
Mr. K. Cornwallis. -40, 800, and 1500 metres.
Mr. R. P Grable.-800 and 1500 metres.
Mr. P. M. Edwards.- 1500 metres, 5 miles.
Mr. G. Fowler-Dixon.-Marathon race.
Lieutenant Wyndham Halswell. 400 and 800 metres.
Lieutenant H. C. Hawtrey.-1500 metres, 5 miles, and Marathon race.
Mr. J. W. Horne.-400 and 800 metres.
Mr. J. McGough-800 and 100 metres.
Mr. R. C. Rend. -100 and 40 metres.
Mr. G. S. Robertson.-Throwing the discus.
Mr. D. Walters. -100 and 400 metres. Hurdles.
Mr. H. G. Weber.-6 miles Marathon race.
Mr. R. E. Wilkinson.-Walking.
Lord Desborough, Lord Howard de Walden, Sir C. Diff Gordon, Mr. C. N. Robinson, Mr. Edgar Seligman, Mr. Theodore Cook.
Swimming: --Four competitors.
Cycling.-Poor competitors.
Gymnastics.- Three competitors.
There may also be one or two independent competitors. The last day for receiving entries was March 22.

Quite a large proportion of the athletes are well-known Oxford or Cambridge men. Although the United States is sending a number of excellent representatives, some at least of the flat races ought to fall to England. Mr. Churchill, Mr. McGough, Mr. Crabbe, Lieutenant Halswell, and Mr. Cornwallis in particular ought to give a good account of themselves. It is fully expected that most of the honours for the athletic sports will be divided between England and America.

There ought to be bands playing and colours flying when the contingent sets off. Lord Howard de Walden goes out on his yacht, accompanied by Lord Desborough and Mr. Corke amongst others, but most of the competitors will leave Victoria at 10 a.m. on April 16. They journey by way of Paris, Brindisi, Corfa, and Patras to Athens, which will be reached on the 20th. Special committees have been formed at Cerfa and Patras to tête them on the way. As the athletic events do not begin till the 27th, the majority will have a full week's rest to prepare for the tusale. The contingent is due to leave Athens on the return journey on May 5, reaching London on the evening of the 9th.

At Athens King Edward and Queen Alexandra are fully expected to attend the games. Before the death of the Queen's father it was understood to be their Majesties' intention to visit Greece about the end of April, but it was thought that that event might modify the programme. It is significant, however that the second cruiser squadron, under Prince Louis of Battenberg, has been ordered to anchor in Phaleron Bay, near Piræus, from April 20 to May 1. The last time the squadron was there was when the Queen visited Greece. The German Emperor will be cruising in the Mediterranean in the third week of April, and although no official confirmation is forthcoming, it is believed that he too will go to Athens.

The historic capital of the Hellenic nation will be a sight for the gods during the ten days the games are in progress. Every nation in Europe, the United States, and many Asiatic peoples will be represented. The event is to be made the occasion of a pilgrimage of Greek from Egypt, the remote parts of Asia Minor and from many more distant lands. Fêtes, galas, and receptions, with gorgeous illuminations, and decorative splendour, will be added to the attractions. The Acropolis by night will be a blaze of light. Special arrangements are being made to allow the visitors to see the " lions" of Greece, and excursions are being promoted to Ægino and Salamine.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN CONCESSION.
div.p: STAY OF EXECUTION GRANTED.

In the Court of Appeal, before Lords Justices Vanghan-Williams, Stirling, and Fletcher Moulton, last week, the hearing was resumed of the application of the defendants in the case of Diamant v. Bewick Morrint and Co., for a stay of execution pending an appeal in the action tried in the King's Bench Division before Mr. Justice Lawrance and a special jury.

The action was brought by Dr. Hermann Diamant to recover from the defendant, damages in respect of an alleged breach of contract relating to a turquoise mining concession in the Sinai Peninsula. The jury found for the plaintiff on the claim for £72, and judgment was entered accordingly. Defendants recovered judgment again at the plaintiff on their counterclaim for £100. Mr. Lawrance refused to stay execution with a view to the defendants appealing from the verdict. Hence the present application.

Mr. J. R. Atkin, in support of the application, said it had been arranged between himself and his learned friends representing the plaintiff that there should be a stay of execution on the defendants bringing £625 into Court within four days and paying the taxed costs to the plaintiff's solicitors.
Order accordingly.

div.head: BY RAIL TO THE 'HOLY MOUNTAIN'.
div.p: OPENING UP THE ANTIQUITIES OF THE SUDAN.

To Egyptologists and antiquaries the new Kareima-Abou Hamed line has high claims. It renders accessible a country rich in archæological remains, dating from remote antiquity up to the 14th century of our era, when the Christian kingdom of Dongola was finally swépt away by the Moslems of Sennar. Along the banks of the Nile in the reach skirted by the new railway are many ruined churches; mouas taries, and fortress of the Christian era in Dongola, which will well repay examination. But the place of greatest interest passed by the railway is Jebel Barkal, the Holy Mountain of the ancient Egyptians, a flat topped hill rising abruptly from the desert, and on the opposite bank of the river is the village of Merowe. Here, or close by, was the Ethiopian city of Napata, and in the neighborhood are many pyramids and temples which have never yet been scientifically examined. That reproach the archæological world now proposes to remove.

The railway, too, passes Ambukol and Korti places famous in the annals of the ill-fated expedition for the relief of General Gordon, and the place where Colonel Donald Stewart and Mr. Prank Power, the French Correul Herbin, and nineteen Greeks, sent from Khartoum by Enrdon to meet Lord Wolseley, were decoyed ashore and murdered by the Mahdists in September, 1884.

div.head: THE EGYPTIANS AT HOME.
div.p: We extract the following from Dr. James Henry Brearted's "History of Egypt from the Earliest Times to the Persian Conquest" (20s. et). The author is Professor of Egyptology and Oriental History in the University of Chicago, and Director of Haskall Oriental Museum. From Book II., which is dévoted to the Old Kingdom, we take this sketch of the Ancient Egyptians in their ordinary home life:

The houses of the rich, the noble and official class, were large and commodious. Methen, a great noble of the third dynasty, built a house over three hundred and thirty feet square. The materials were wood and sun-dried brick and the construction was light and airy, as suited the climate. There were many latticed windows, on all sides the walls of the living rooms were largely a mere skeleton like those of many. Japanese houses. Against winds and sand storms they could be closed by dropping gaily coloured hangings. Even the palace of the king, though of course fortified, was of this light construction ; hence the cities of ancient Egypt have disappeared entirely or left but monds containing a few scanty fragments of ruined walls. Beds, chairs, stools, and chests of ebony, inlaid with ivory in the finest workmanship, formed the chief articles of furniture.

Little or no use was made of tables, but the rich vessels of alabaster, and other costly stoner, of copper, or sometimes of gold and silver, were placed upon bases and standards which raised them from the floor. The floors were covered with heavy rugs upon which guests, especially ladies, frequently sat, in preference to the chairs and stools. The food was rich and varied ; we find that even the dead desired in the hereafter "ten different kinds of meat, five kinds of poultry, sixteen kinds of bread and cakes, six kinds of wine, four kinds of beer, eleven kinds of fruit, besides all sorts of sweet and many other things." The costume of the ancient lords was simple in the extreme; it consisted merely of a white linen kilt, secured above the hips with a girdle or band, and hanging often hardly to the knees, or again in another style to the calf of the leg. The head was commonly shaven, and two styles of wig, one short and curly the other with long straight Iocks parted in the middle, were worn on all state occasions. A broad collar, often inlaid with costly stones, generally hung from the neck but otherwise the body was bare from the waist up. With long staff in hand, the gentlemen of the day was ready to receive his visitors, or to make a tour of inspection about his estate. His lady and her daughters all appeared in costumes even more simple. They were clothed in a thin, close-fitting, sleeveless, white linen garment hanging from the breast to the ankles, and supported by two bands Parking over the shoulders. The skirt, as a modern modiste would say, "lacked fullness," and there was barely freedom to walk. A long wig, a cullar and necklace, and a pair of bracelets completed the lady's costume. Neither she nor her lord was fond of sandals ; although they now and then wore them.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le Caire, 23 Mars.
Le taux de l'escompte à Londres vient d'être élevé de 1/8 à 3 5/8.

Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 à 90 1/2. L'Unifiée a également réactionné de 1/8 & 105 7/8, ainsi que la National Bank à 28 1/4. La Daïra et l'Agricole sont restées in variées à 18 1/4 et 10. * A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Égyptien a perdu 3 francs à 797. La Banque d'Athènes a gagné 1 freno à 152.
Notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, calme et sans affaires, avec des cours stationnaires ou faibles sur toutes les valeurs, à très peu d'exceptions près.

L'action Crédit Foncier est revenue à 796. La Daïra, assez animée, a fait 18 1/3. La Béhérá a faibli à 37 1/2; l'Agricole da Nile a 284. La part de fondateur Immobilière est descendue à 615. L'action Enterprise and Development est remontée à 11 15/16.
La part de fondateur Land Allotment a haussé jusqu'à 175 pour clôturer à 165.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a avancé à 4 1/4; la part de fondateur est restée à LE. 15.
L'action Menzaleh a fait 4 3/4 ; la part de fondateur est revenge à 125. Le Khedivial Mail Line a clôturé à 43 sh. 6. Les Sucreries sont remontées à 14 -16.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nangovich ont été offerts à 17 et les Upper Egypt à 5 5/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, los Estates ont été traités entre 1 15/16 et 2; la part de fondateur à avance a 13. Les Delta Land sont revenus à 3 3/8-7/16 et les Egyptian Constructions à 1 9/16.

Le mouvement qui tend à se dessiner sur les Land Allotment serait dû à des informations très favorables reçues de Chypre, ou Sir William Willoooks est allé arrêter, avec le gouvernement de l'île, les bases de l'arrangement relatif à la création de l'Agricultural Bank of Cyprus.
Suivant ces informations, Sir William Willcocks aurait obtenu pour la nouvelle Banque des concessions extrêmement avantageuses,

Ainsi, toutes les fois que, pour un exercice quelconque pendant la durée de la Société, les intérêts recouvrés dans l'exercice, ainsi que les sommes perçues sur les prêts en termes échus et non recouvrés des exercices précédents, n'at tiendraient pas la somme nécessaire 1. pour couvrir les dépenses et le montant des prêts en termes échus et non recouvrés ; 2. pour laisser un bénéfice net représentant le 4 % da capital engagé en prêts aux cultivateurs, le gouvernement de Chypre versera à la Banque, à titre de subvention, le solde de la somme nécessaire, en cas d'insuffisance de fonds de réserve.

On sait que l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt jouit ici du même privilège, à cette différence notable près que le gouvernement égyptien garantit indirectement un bénéfice net représentant le 8 % da capital engagé en prêts aux fellabe.

On s'attendait que les pourparlers engagés depuis quelque temps entre l'Est et la Société des Eaux du Caire relativement aux terrains avoisinant les filtres de l'Abbassieh abou. tissent dans un bref délai.

Le gouvernement serait, assure-t-on, disposé accorder à la Société l'autorisation de vendre 088 terrains (one cinquantaine de feddans) aux mêmes conditions que ceux du Vieux Cai re, soit 8/3 pour la Compagnie et 1/3 pour l'Etat.
Le bruit court depuis hier soir que l'Ibrabimieh Plongbing Co. serait amenée à déposer Bon bilan par suite de la faillite des Sucreries.

Nous ne saurions dire à quel point cette rumour est exacte. Un fait certain, c'est que les actions Ploughing ne sont plus cotées à la Bourse. Le prix de £3, indiqué jusqu'à 088 derniers temps, était parement nominal; 088 titres ne trouvaient pas preneurs même a £1.

Suivant des informations d'Alexandrie, les recettes da New Khedivial, appartenant à la Splendid Hotels Co., vont toujours augmentant dans les proportions les plus promettantes. Ainsi les recettes de la 2ème décade du mois courant accusent une augmentation d'environ L.E. 350 sur la période correspondante de l'année dernière.

Ce surplus important est appelé encore à s'accroître considérablement, étant donné, comme nous l'avons déjà fait observer, que les travaux d'agrandissement de l'Hôtel viennent d'être terminés et qu'on est aux approches de la saison d'été.

Il est officiellement annoncé que les actionnaires du Comptoir Financier et Commercial sont convoqués en Assemblée générale extraordinaire le 7 avril prochain, au siège social à Alexandrie, pour délibérer sur la proposition d'augmentation du capital, la distribution d'un dividende intérimaire, des modifications aux Statuts et la nomination d'un administrateur.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie.
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de canalisation des rues El Ghazali et El Margani.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 6.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 8 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour Canalisation rues Gazali et Margani.

Le cautionnement on le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 3 Avril 1906 á midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
(Signe) W. P. CHATAWAY, Alexandrie, le 22 Mars 1906. 97562-3-2
AVIS.
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de 100 regards en pierre.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé en Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 avril 1906.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniture de regards on pierre."

Le cautionnement on le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et an plus tard le 24 avril 1906 á midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les condi. tions ci-dessus sera écartée.
(Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY. Alexandrie, le 22 Mars 1906. 27563-82

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
